data.text: Contents
Introduction

This document is to ensure that all staff are applying the mandatory National guidelines and performing the World Health Organisations Five Steps to Safer Surgery. The Mid and South Essex Hospital Group have a duty of care to act in the best interests of the patient. Established by the World Alliance for Patient Safety. The Safer Surgery, Safer Lives initiative was launched by the WHO in 2008 to develop patient safety throughout the perioperative phase of care to reduce the number of surgical errors that could lead to a patient death. The initiative highlighted the need for clinical acknowledgement and will take in hand important safety issues which include inadequate safety practices, avoidable surgical site infection and to increase communication between team members.
The Team debrief is conducted at the end of each session and should be encouraged within all teams to enable all members of the team to raise any matters of concern that they may have.
As described in the Patient Safety First campaign the Five Steps to Safer Surgery are the Briefing, the three stages of the WHO checklist and the final Debrief. The process is intended to
Improve teamwork and communication within teams. This may improve the organisation of the operating list and may contribute to better performance during a critical incident.
Increase and improve team awareness of patient safety issues.
Ensure that all patient safety checks are undertaken and any concerns are shared with theatre team.
Ensure that every part of the patient's care/intervention is shared throughout the patient's journey whilst under the care of the Anaesthetic and Surgical /Interventional Radiology Team.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Ensure that all staff understand that this is mandatory for every patient to ensure patients individual care needs are identified at the start of each surgical procedure.
Each patient will have the WHO Safety Checklist performed throughout their procedure.
Any amendments to the WHO Safety Check list or policy are subject to approval at senior management level within the MSE Hospital Anaesthetic and Surgical Directorate.
For Theatres, any changes particularly omissions should be ratified through the LOCIPPS group.
For imaging any changes particularly omissions will be identified through the incident report mechanism, ratified by the clinical director and fed back to the imaging services manager.

In the event of an outbreak of infection, flu epidemic or major incident the application of this policy would still apply. The checklist will still support an increase in precision times of crisis when better communication and attention to detail is essential.

These guidelines apply to all staff regardless of grade or profession working for the MSE Hospital Group who are involved in a patient surgical or interventional care pathway where the WHO Safety Checklist is required.
This list is not exhaustive as other areas performing invasive procedures may be required to adopt WHO safety checks.
The surgical checklist was adapted by the NPSA in 2009, incorporating and addressing the issues to improve surgical safety.
By using a surgical checklist) there was a notable reduction in perioperative morbidity and mortality. Haynes et al(2009) .
The Five Safer Steps to Safer Surgery are the Briefing, followed by the three stages of the WHO Checklist and finally the Debrief. The process is intended to:
Improve teamwork and communication within teams. Intended to improve the organisation of the operating list and lead to improved communication and performance in a critical incident.

Standardise previous safety checks to formalise and normalise patients safety checks from the time they enter the Anaesthetic Room/Operating Theatre through to the end of their procedure in the operating theatre.
Progress compliance to ensure that all of the aspects of patients' individualized care are complied with. i.e. (VTE) prophylaxis.
Increase and improve team awareness of patient safety issues.

data.text: Role and Responsibilities within the Trust
The LocSSips committee is responsible for compliance with all aspects of the WHO Checklist being up to date.
The responsibility for the completion of the WHO Safety Checklist process falls under the team looking after the patient during the Interventional procedure.

The Medical Director has executive accountability for the delivery and implementation of the policy on a day to day basis. The Medical Director receives managerial assurance and provides the Trust board with effective implementation and action of noncompliance.
The completion of the WHO Safety Checklist process is undertaken by the team that are managing the patients care during the Interventional procedure.

The Consultant/Operating Surgeon/Radiologist is ultimately accountable for ensuring the full completion of the WHO Safety Checklist. They are also responsible for attending the Team Brief. Completion of the “Time Out” and second component of the “Sign Out” sections of the WHO Safety Checklist can be signed by a member of the Surgical/Imaging Team.
The Anaesthetist is responsible for attending the Team Brief. A member of the Anaesthetic/Imaging team may confirm the “Sign In” on behalf of the Anaesthetist.
The Theatre Manager ensures that the Anaesthetic and Theatre staff are aware of the policy and its implementation.
The Theatre Matrons ensures all staff including medical staff are compliant with the policy. The WHO Audits are monitored and reported by the Theatre Matrons.
Medical staff are fully responsible for reading this and other policies in accordance with Trust Policy.
The Theatre Practice Facilitator ensures that all new and existing staff are trained and competent to meet their individual and team responsibilities in relation to this policy.

The Imaging service manager is responsible for ensuring that the Imaging WHO Safety Checklist is being followed at all times. It is their responsibility to ensure that staffs are given the policy on induction. The Imaging/Quality Managers are responsible for ensuring noncompliance is monitored and noncompliance is escalated and managed.
Theatre Team Leader/Radiographer are responsible for ensuring the Team Brief/Debrief and the WHO Safety Checklist occur for every patient within their areas of responsibility.

Theatre Team participate fully in this policy as a professional practitioner as a member of the operative/procedural team. All staff are responsible for ensuring that they read and understand the policy, related documents and implement the guidance into their practice.

Theatre Recovery/Imaging Recovery teams are responsible for ensuring 100% compliance of the WHO Checklist process when taking over the patient care in Recovery. Noncompliance is reported to the Theatre Matron/ Imaging managers and Clinical Incident form completed.
WHO Checklist and team brief
The team brief and the WHO Safety Checklist are integral parts of the patient pathway for those patients undergoing an interventional procedure. All team members must be present for all stages.
The procedure will consist of 4 steps as follows, plus a debrief at the end.
Step 1 Team Brief

5.3.1 The principle is for team members to introduce themselves, outline the work for the session and discuss each case individually. It is conducted in the clinical area that is managing the patient's procedure. It will be attended by the whole team including the Consultant/Operating Surgeon/Anaesthetist. A template is used to ensure that all cases are discussed in a structured manner.

5.3.2 Each member of the team introduces themselves. This is intended to improve communication, teamwork and incorporate human factors within the process. Discussing each case in turn provides a simple way for the team to share vital information about each patient's procedure and discuss actual and potential safety issues. The team Brief is an opportunity to organise staff and equipment to ensure the maximum efficiency and utilisation of the session.
The sterility of the instruments /procedure packs, and availability of prosthesis and other relevant equipment is confirmed. Also the pregnancy status where relevant.
Step 2 Sign In

5.4.1  The principle is to make sure the correct patient is going to have the correct procedure by checking their identity, site and procedure. Sign In section is completed when the patient arrives in the Anaesthetic room/Theatre prior to any intervention. The patient or their advocate must verbally confirm the patient's identity. It is the responsibility of the Anaesthetist (theatres) or the Radiologist (imaging) to ensure that this section is completed and signed. The patient, their wrist band, the consent forms and appropriate surgical site markings are all used to ensure that the right patient is having the correct procedure on the correct side. If Anaesthetic Nerve Blocks are employed during the anaesthetic phase, there should be a specific mention to reduce the chance of wrong side blocks.(Stop Before You Block) procedure is used and further checks completed to ensure correct side and site of Anaesthetic Block.
Step 3 Time Out

5.5.1  The principle is to reconfirm that the correct patient is about to undergo the correct procedure and that this can be carried out safely. The Time Out section is completed immediately prior to the surgery/procedure commencing. The whole team pause so that this may be completed. The Surgical/Radiology Team are responsible for the completion of the Time Out section of the WHO Safety Checklist. The patient's identity and the planned procedure are confirmed. The sterility of the instruments /procedure packs, and availability of prosthesis and other relevant equipment is confirmed. Patient warming, VTE, essential imaging availability and any non-routine steps anticipated should be confirmed at this time. For the imaging department confirmation of the medical records being present should be documented.
Step 4 Sign out

5.6.1  The principle is to confirm that the correct procedure has been undertaken and to note relevant post-operative care and that specimen are prepared and labelled correctly. Sign out section is completed for each patient before the end of each procedure, for example skin closure. All team members must be present during the completion of the Sign Out section. The registered practitioner has responsibility for completion of both sections of the Sign Out. It is verbally confirmed that the name of the procedure and coding are correctly recorded. The Scrub practitioner verifies that the instruments, swab and sharp counts are correct and that all accessories used during the procedure are accurately documented. It is confirmed that specimens taken during the procedure have been correctly labelled and sent in the correct medium for processing. Any equipment problems have been addressed, recorded and reported accordingly. It is confirmed that any patient concerns such as VTE prophylaxis and post procedural patient care is agreed and documented.
Team Debrief
5.7.1  The debrief is conducted at the end of the session and should be encouraged within all teams to enable all members of the team raise any matters or concerns that they may have.
Data Collection

5.8.1  For patients passing through either Theatre Recovery or Imaging Recovery Teams: The Recovery Practitioner will check that all sections of the WHO Safety Checklist have been completed and escalated if non-compliance is identified.
Audit

5.9.1  Each department should conduct an audit to ensure the checklists are being used. Ideally the auditor should be from a different team. The summary of the audit results should be presented to the LocSSIPS committee. The Trusts observational audit form should be used. The number of cases and frequency of audit will vary by department.
Training requirements

Theatre staff are required to have mandatory training that is specific to their role. (ISSO9001:2015, monitors compliance at Broomfield Hospital Site) All staff must complete competencies and be assessed for competence.
All new staff will be accompanied by a mentor until they have provided documented evidence of competence.
All Students are accompanied by a training supervisor
All members of staff are obliged to report any breaches and concerns of the use of the WHO Safety Checklist that they may have to their employer and by completing an Incident Report Form.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Divisional Governance Group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Divisional Governance Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
